When Obama and Putin meet Monday , the agenda will be full of sticky issues . Obama , Putin gird for frosty face-off
When President Barack Obama meets Monday with Russian President Vladimir Putin , both leaders will be under huge pressure to demonstrate strength to voters back home .
Putin just got reelected in part by bashing America , and he has protesters on the streets in Moscow and domestic political rivals looking for signs of weakness .
Obama is running for reelection against a rival who has labeled Russia “ without question our No . 1 political foe . ”
The sticky issues on the agenda when the two sit down in Los Cabos , Mexico , during the G-20 meeting won ’ t be easily resolved , including escalating tensions over Syria , Iran , missile defense and Afghanistan .
“ They ’ re walking on ice at a time when the climate is relatively warm , ” said Zbigniew Brzezinski , the former national security adviser for President Jimmy Carter .
Not a lot of diplomatic progress is expected in what ’ s likely to be one of Obama ’ s last major international meetings before November . But even the slightest hint that he isn ’ t being tough enough carries political risk . At Obama ’ s last Russian talks while in South Korea in March , his hot-mike suggestion to then-Russian President Dmitry Medvedev that he would have more flexibility on missile defense talks “ after my election ” dominated the news back home .
Though Obama got along well with Medvedev and Medvedev ’ s allegiance to Putin is perhaps the worst-kept secret of international politics , Obama hasn ’ t had much of a relationship with Putin . They ’ ve met once , over a traditional Russian breakfast during Obama ’ s 2009 trip to Moscow , when Putin caught Obama off guard by adding a proposal for visa-free travel to the agenda without warning .
“ All foreign policy is partly domestic politics , ” said James Collins , who served as the American ambassador to Russia in the last years of Bill Clinton ’ s presidency and the beginning of Putin ’ s first term . “ Neither man comes to this with a domestic political context that is particularly conducive to making gestures to the other or taking risks . ”
Putin , after all , is the man who started his relationship with then-President George W. Bush with a warm meeting in which Bush claimed he ’ d looked into his Russian counterpart ’ s soul . But the relationship deteriorated so much over the next eight years that one of Obama ’ s early acts was sending Secretary of State Hillary Clinton overseas with a “ reset ” button to symbolize the fresh start he hoped for on issues ranging from arms control to conversations over the Mideast peace process .
But Putin has a flair for the theatrical : He ’ s staged a supposed stumble over ancient pottery while snorkeling and has sung “ Blueberry Hill ” on Russian national television . He doesn ’ t like to concede anything and has a history of lecturing world leaders and stonewalling them when he doesn ’ t get what he wants .

When Obama and Putin meet Monday, the agenda will be full of sticky issues. Obama, Putin gird for frosty face-off

When President Barack Obama meets Monday with Russian President Vladimir Putin, both leaders will be under huge pressure to demonstrate strength to voters back home.

Putin just got reelected in part by bashing America, and he has protesters on the streets in Moscow and domestic political rivals looking for signs of weakness.

Obama is running for reelection against a rival who has labeled Russia “without question our No. 1 political foe.”

The sticky issues on the agenda when the two sit down in Los Cabos, Mexico, during the G-20 meeting won’t be easily resolved, including escalating tensions over Syria, Iran, missile defense and Afghanistan.

“They’re walking on ice at a time when the climate is relatively warm,” said Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national security adviser for President Jimmy Carter.

Not a lot of diplomatic progress is expected in what’s likely to be one of Obama’s last major international meetings before November. But even the slightest hint that he isn’t being tough enough carries political risk. At Obama’s last Russian talks while in South Korea in March, his hot-mike suggestion to then-Russian President Dmitry Medvedev that he would have more flexibility on missile defense talks “after my election” dominated the news back home.

Though Obama got along well with Medvedev and Medvedev’s allegiance to Putin is perhaps the worst-kept secret of international politics, Obama hasn’t had much of a relationship with Putin. They’ve met once, over a traditional Russian breakfast during Obama’s 2009 trip to Moscow, when Putin caught Obama off guard by adding a proposal for visa-free travel to the agenda without warning.

“All foreign policy is partly domestic politics,” said James Collins, who served as the American ambassador to Russia in the last years of Bill Clinton’s presidency and the beginning of Putin’s first term. “Neither man comes to this with a domestic political context that is particularly conducive to making gestures to the other or taking risks.”

Putin, after all, is the man who started his relationship with then-President George W. Bush with a warm meeting in which Bush claimed he’d looked into his Russian counterpart’s soul. But the relationship deteriorated so much over the next eight years that one of Obama’s early acts was sending Secretary of State Hillary Clinton overseas with a “reset” button to symbolize the fresh start he hoped for on issues ranging from arms control to conversations over the Mideast peace process.

But Putin has a flair for the theatrical: He’s staged a supposed stumble over ancient pottery while snorkeling and has sung “Blueberry Hill” on Russian national television. He doesn’t like to concede anything and has a history of lecturing world leaders and stonewalling them when he doesn’t get what he wants.
